On 9/23/05, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
>
>        Yes this =
is limited in the sense that it makes no provision that the
> player might =
be playing against an imperfect opponent, but I see no
> plausible way to q=
uantify that anyway, e.g. how many ways are there of
> being "imperfect"?

=
Well, but that's an important aspect of a good, robust player of any
game, =
isn't it?  A very good player of any game will learn to find and
exploit we=
akness of an opponent.  If we can't do this at the level of
Tic-Tac-Toe, wh=
at's the point of tackling more difficult games like
Checkers or Chess or G=
o?
